OVERVIEW: The Presa series consists of deep, well drained soils that formed in material weathered from sandstone and shale.  Presa soils are on steep slopes of mountains and canyons and have slopes of 15 to 80 percent.  The mean annual precipitation is about 35 inches and the mean annual air temperature is about 36 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive Typic Haplocryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Presa cobbly loam, forested.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01 & 02--2 to 0 inches; forest litter in various stages of decomposition.
A1--0 to 2 inches; yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) cobbly loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; moderate thin platy structure parting to moderate fine granular; soft, very friable; common very fine, fine and medium roots, few coarse roots; many very fine and fine pores; 20 percent gravel, 20 percent cobblestones; strongly acid (pH 5.4); abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 4 inches thick)
A2--2 to 5 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) gravelly loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; moderate fine granular structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly plastic; common very fine and fine roots, few medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine pores; 30 percent gravel, few cobblestones; medium acid (pH 5.8); clear smooth boundary.  (2 to 15 inches thick)
Blt--5 to 13 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) very gravelly loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly plastic; common very fine and fine roots, few medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine pores; 45 percent gravel, 5 percent cobblestones; many thin films on rock fragments; medium acid (pH 5.8); gradual wavy boundary.  (6 to 10 inches thick)
B21t--13 to 24 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) extremely gravelly loam, light olive brown (2.5Y 5/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly plastic; common very fine, fine, and medium roots; many very fine and fine pores; 50 percent gravel, 25 percent cobblestones, 10 percent stones; many thin clay films on rock fragments; medium acid (pH 5.8); clear wavy boundary.  (8 to 20 inches thick)
B22t--24 to 34 inches; pale yellow (2.5Y 7/4) extremely cobbly loam, light olive brown (2.5Y 5/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly plastic; few very fine and common medium roots; many very fine and fine pores; 45 percent gravel, 30 percent cobblestones, 20 percent stones; many thin clay films on rock fragments; medium acid (pH 5.8); clear wavy boundary.  (5 to 20 inches thick)
B23t--34 to 43 inches; pale yellow (2.5Y 7/4) extremely cobbly sandy clay loam, light olive brown (2.5Y 5/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, few very fine roots; many very fine and fine pores; 45 percent gravel, 30 percent cobblestones, 20 percent stones; common thin clay films on faces of peds and on rock fragments; medium acid (pH 5.8); clear wavy boundary.  (8 to 16 inches thick)
B3t--43 to 52 inches; light yellowish brown (2.5Y 6/4) extremely stony sandy clay loam, olive brown (2.5Y 4/4) moist; very weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few very fine roots; many very fine and fine pores; 5 percent gravel, 15 percent cobblestones, 70 percent stones; many moderately thick clay films on faces of peds and on rock fragments; slightly acid (pH 6.4); clear wavy boundary.  (10 to 20 inches thick)
C--52 to 76 inches; light yellowish brown (2.5Y 6/4) extremely stony sandy loam, olive brown (2.5Y 4/4) moist, massive; slightly hard, very friable; few very fine roots; many very fine and fine pores; 25 percent cobblestones, 60 percent stones; slightly acid (pH 6.4).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Taos County, New Mexico; section 27, T.24N., R.15E.; photo number 1451.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The annual soil temperature ranges from 34 to 38 degrees F. and the mean summer temperature ranges from 36 to 42 degrees F.  The solum ranges from 40 to 90 inches thick.  Rock fragments are angular pebbles, cobbles, and stones.
The A1 horizon has value of 4 through 6 dry, 2 through 4 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3 dry or moist.  It is loam or sandy loam.  This horizon is missing in some pedons.  Rock fragments in the A1 and A2 horizons range from 10 to 35 percent.
The B2t horizon has hue of 7.5YR, 10YR or 2.5Y, value of 5 through 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 or 4.  It is loam, sandy clay loam, and clay loam and has 20 to 30 percent clay.  Rock fragments range from 35 to 95 percent.
The B3t horizon has hue of 10YR or 2.5Y, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 or 4.  It is sandy loam, sandy clay loam, or clay loam.  Rock fragments range from 50 to 90 percent.
The C horizon, where present, has hue of 2.5Y or 5Y.  It is sandy loam, sandy clay loam, or clay loam.  Rock fragments range from 60 to 95 percent.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Agneston, Angostura, Cloud Peak, Cundiyo, Duchesne, Frisco, Gambler, Granile, Hyattsville (t), Jorge, Kebler, Lake Creek, Lakehelen (t), Larand, Leadville, Lulude, Macfarlane, Tenrag (t), Tolvar and Zabel (t) series.  Agneston, Cloud Peak, Hyattsville, Kebler, Lake Creek, Lakehelen, and Lulude soils have bedrock at depths of less than 40 inches.  Angostura soils have a mixed B&A horizon and have a mean summer soil temperature of 42 to 46 degrees F.  Cundiyo, Jorge, and Macfarlane soils have less than 20 percent clay in the argillic horizon.  Duchesne soils have argillic horizons less than 20 inches thick.  Frisco soils have A2 horizons thicker than 11 inches.  Gambler, Granile, Larand, Tolvar, snd Zabel soils have mixed A&B horizons.  Leadville and Tenrag soils have hue of 7.5YR or 5YR.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Presa soils are on mountain and canyon side slopes at elevations of 10,000 to 12,000 feet.  Slopes are 0 to 80 percent.  These soils formed in material weathered from sandstone and shale.  The climate is continental with mean annual air temperatures ranging from 32 to 38 degrees F. and the summer temperature ranges from 36 to 40 degrees F.  The annual precipitation ranges from 30 to 40 inches.  The frost free season is 50 to 70 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Jaroso, Mascarenas, and Penitente soils and the competing Angostura soils.  Jarosa soils have a clayey, skeletal control section.  Mascarenas soils are deeper than 24 inches to the argillic horizon.  Penitente soils have an umbric epipedon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff; moderate permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Timber production, wildlife habitat, recreation, and watershed.  Vegetation is Engelmann spruce, subalpine fir, with an understory of kinnikinnick, and whortleberry.  Scattered grasses are timber oatgrass, mountain brome, nodding brome, and tufted hairgrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  This series is of moderate extent in northern New Mexico.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Taos Area, New Mexico, 1976.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
